content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looks good!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: An easy one-dimensional problem with a small task. Since it can be implemented fast if you understand the basic concept it's an acceptable clash of code type of problem as far as I'm concerned.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Un petit clash pas trop dur, faisable dans les  temps dans je pense probabblement tous les langages

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: The puzzle is clever and rapid to solve... if you have the good point of view.

anyway, I think that the tests are sufficiently clear to avoid this problem

I like this problem very much (the fact that you have to think out of the box and totally disbelief the collisions is a very nice twist, in my opinion)

It seems to me that if  we have only 1 nanobot , facing left and with initial position 0, the given solution will answer "0 seconds".  That means that the nanobot stops immediately and doesn't go "beyond" the left end. Should we modifiy the word "beyond" ?

For instance , we could say : "Once a nanobot gets for the first time  at either end of the working lane, it stops moving immediately."
Nice one
For the example test case, shouldn't the nanobots at positions 0 and 4 initially immediately stop moving when the system starts (i.e., at time t = 0s)?
The collision detail is somewhat misleading for a quick coding challenge, but I think it’s a fun puzzle that can still be solved rapidly, as long as you don’t get sidetracked by the collisions.

Input
* Line 2: Please change as follows:
  • Add "(in meters)" after "[[m]]".

  • Change "nanobot" to "nanobots".

  • Change "from the left end of" to "listed from left to right along".

* Line 3: Please change the description to:
[[n]] characters, either {{L}} or {{R}}, representing the directions of the nanobots, listed from left to right along the working lane.

Also note that the number of characters is n, not m.

Constraints
* Please change the third constraint to:
No two nanobots share the same initial position.

Cases
* Please delete all the trailing newlines in input.

* Please delete all the trailing newlines in output.

* Test 3: Please change the direction of the first nanobot to "R" as there are currently no visible tests with >1 nanobot and this configuration (only Validator 4 includes it). The change has the added benefit of causing the output of Test 3 to be different from that of Validator 3.

Thanks.

Note:
This clash is very similar to an existing puzzle:
https://www.codingame.com/training/easy/robot-show
However, this clash specifies the initial direction of the robots while the puzzle doesn't, which might make the clash slightly easier.

Ye you're right
Should I delete it?

You're right to point this out. The nanobot at position 4 is at the right end of the working lane and initially facing left. That makes it unclear whether it'll start moving to the left or stop immediately.

The second paragraph in Goal section should be expanded to clarify that a nanobot only stops immediately if it's both at the end and facing outwards.

Wait, loop hole
I put goes beyond

Could you specify that "goes beyond" means a position of m < 0 or m > w? You should also add a test case where one nanobot is at m=0 facing L, another is at m=w facing R, and the minimum time required is t=1.

For the case suggested by @User123, the author's code gives 0 as the answer.

Would the author please follow up @User123's latest comment?
lim x->0 (robot moving x seconds) will return true for the given test case, therefore x=0. t doesn't have to be integer
Also updated the problem, putting the width is negligible and output t to the nearest integer.

This whole "goes beyond" concept sounds very confusing. I think @5DN1L's first comment about checking for the direction of the nanobot works, although it makes the problem slightly unintuitive.

Alternatively, stick to your original problem (stop at m=0 or m=w), but generate test cases such that no nanobot starts at either of these two endpoints?

Would it be helpful to add a simple example (like the one below) to Goal section to illustrate how direction and position affect the time it takes for a nanobot to stop?

Assume the working lane is {{5}} meters long and there is a single nanobot on it.
• If a nanobot starts at the <<left end>> and <<facing left>>, it stops immediately: {{0}} seconds.
• If a nanobot starts at the <<left end>> and <<facing right>>, it reaches the right end in {{5}} seconds and stops moving.
• If a nanobot starts at the <<right end>> and <<facing left>>, it reaches the left end in {{5}} seconds and stops moving.
• If a nanobot starts at the <<right end>> and <<facing right>>, it stops immediately: {{0}} seconds.
What do you think, @User123? Does my suggestion above help, or is there something more that should be done?
I think that would help. Just waiting on @The Capra Aegagrus Hircus 2000 to make the call :)
My question is how do I add example statement?

Just add the text to the Goal section:

Examples:
Assume the working lane is {{5}} meters long and there is a single nanobot on it.
• If a nanobot starts at the <<left end>> and <<facing left>>, it stops immediately: {{0}} seconds.
• If a nanobot starts at the <<left end>> and <<facing right>>, it reaches the right end in {{5}} seconds and stops moving.
• If a nanobot starts at the <<right end>> and <<facing left>>, it reaches the left end in {{5}} seconds and stops moving.
• If a nanobot starts at the <<right end>> and <<facing right>>, it stops immediately: {{0}} seconds.

@The Capra Aegagrus Hircus 2000:
Would you please consider adding the above examples to the Goal section? Thanks.
No, the tasks and the solutions are slightly different.
Please let me know when you're done following up all the points above. Thanks.
I fixed it, except for listed from left to right along, because it's unordered

Ah, I get your point. In that case…

* Line 2: Please change "nanobot" to "nanobots".

* Line 3: Please add "given in the exact same order as in Line 2".

Thanks.
